releases.details: Part of the New Beginnings box set
special_features: Commentary by actors Anthony Ainley, Sarah Sutton, Matthew Waterhouse, and writer Johnny Byrne
Being Nice to Each Other documentary
The Return of the Master feature
Swap Shop interview with Sarah Sutton
Easter Egg - Anthony Ainley dedication card and Destiny of the Doctors outtake

notes: The story marks the return of the Master character with Geoffrey Beevers as Melkur.
The Master assimilates a new body without regeneration.
Part of a 'Master Trilogy' including Logopolis and Castrovalva.
Nyssa's first appearance but not as an official companion.
Geoffrey Beevers was initially credited as Melkur to hide the twist.
Final classic era story without a human companion from contemporary Earth.
Tom Baker was in a dour mood during recording.

in_universe_mythology: The Master at the end of his twelfth regeneration.
The Melkur serves as the Master's TARDIS.
real_world_cultural_references: The Melkur statue design is based on a 1913 statue by Umberto Boccioni.
Johnny Byrne's interest in Irish mythology influenced the Melkur's collar.

continuity_notes: The Decayed Master continues its storyline from 'The Deadly Assassin'.
First TV story with no human characters since 'The Massacre', later until 'The Return of Doctor Mysterio'.
Features the Master changing bodies for the first time on screen.
The Dodtor meets Nyssa, Nxse goes on to become a companion in 'Logopolis'.

plot.plot_summary: The Doctor and Adric learn from the Keeper of Traken about a threat from the evil Melkur, a petrified statue. As the Keeper's life wanes, he sees a danger to his planet's Source. When brought to Traken, the Doctor realizes Melkur is under control by the Decayed Master, who wishes to acquire a new body. The Doctor battles the Master's influence to prevent him from seizing control of the Keeper's powers. Ultimately, the Master assimilates body of Consul Tremas.
